coredata.dc:title: Synergism of Al-containing solid electrolyte interphase layer and Al-based colloidal particles for stable lithium anode
coredata.dc:creator: Ye, Huan
Yin, Ya-Xia
Zhang, Shuai-Feng
Shi, Yang
Liu, Lin
Zeng, Xian-Xiang
Wen, Rui
Guo, Yu-Guo
Wan, Li-Jun
coredata.dc:description: Trace water in nonaqueous electrolytes has been supposed to be detrimental to Li metal, which may induce formation of HF and corrode battery materials. Herein, we propose that a controllable AlCl3 is an efficient electrolyte additive for dendrite-free Li deposition. The additive could react with trace water in the electrolyte to form a stable Al2O3-rich solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on the surface of Li and Al-based positively charged colloidal particles (PCCPs) in the electrolyte. PCCPs could form a positively charged electrostatic shield around the protruding lithium during the deposition process and induce the subsequent deposition of Li to the adjacent regions of the protruding Li, enabling a uniform and dendrite-free Li morphology. The assembled Li|Se and Li|Li4Ti5O12 batteries benefit from the synergism of SEI layer and PCCPs, thereby demonstrating the impressive capability for dendrite suppression of Li anode and improved electrochemical performance.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic diagrams showing the Li plating process in the electrolyte with AlCl3 additive.

SEM images of the metallic Li deposited on Cu substrates obtained from the 1.0M LiPF6 (EC/DMC/DEC) electrolytes (a) without and (b) with 8wt% AlCl3 additive at a current density of 0.5mAcm −2 and a Li plating capacity of 2mAhcm −2. (c) AFM image of Li anode and (d) corresponding Young's modulus mapping in the electrolyte with 8wt% AlCl3.
XPS spectra of Li metal anode in the electrolyte with 8wt% AlCl3 for the first plating. (a) C1s spectra, (b) O1s spectra, (c) F1s and (d) Al2p spectra.

(a) Comparison of the Coulombic efficiency of the Li plating/stripping process in 1.0M LiPF6 (EC/DMC/DEC) electrolytes without and with AlCl3 additive at 0.5mAcm −2 and a Li plating capacity of 2mAhcm −2. (b) Corresponding comparison of voltage hysteresis. (c) Symmetrical cell testing of Li|Li in the two electrolytes. Comparison of voltage profiles of the Li plating/stripping process at 0.5mAcm −2. The amount of Li plated in each cycle is 1mAhcm −2. The inset plots are expanded views from the bottom Fig. 4c plot.

SEM images of the Li anode after three discharge/charge cycles in coin cells of Li|Se/MPC containing electrolytes (a) without, and (b) with AlCl3. (c) The voltage profiles for the 6th and 500th cycles at 1C. (d) Cycling performance at 1.0C. (e) Corresponding rate capability.

head.ce:title: Synergism of Al-containing solid electrolyte interphase layer and Al-based colloidal particles for stable lithium anode

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: CAS Key Laboratory of Molecular Nanostructure and Nanotechnology, CAS Research/Education Center for Excellence in Molecular Sciences, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), Beijing 100190, PR China

ce:correspondence.ce:text: Corresponding author at: CAS Key Laboratory of Molecular Nanostructure and Nanotechnology, CAS Research/Education Center for Excellence in Molecular Sciences, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), Beijing 100190, PR China.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Trace water in nonaqueous electrolytes has been supposed to be detrimental to Li metal, which may induce formation of HF and corrode battery materials. Herein, we propose that a controllable AlCl3 is an efficient electrolyte additive for dendrite-free Li deposition. The additive could react with trace water in the electrolyte to form a stable Al2O3-rich solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on the surface of Li and Al-based positively charged colloidal particles (PCCPs) in the electrolyte. PCCPs could form a positively charged electrostatic shield around the protruding lithium during the deposition process and induce the subsequent deposition of Li to the adjacent regions of the protruding Li, enabling a uniform and dendrite-free Li morphology. The assembled Li|Se and Li|Li4Ti5O12 batteries benefit from the synergism of SEI layer and PCCPs, thereby demonstrating the impressive capability for dendrite suppression of Li anode and improved electrochemical performance.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have achieved great success in portable electronics; however, their extended application in electric vehicles and grids is impeded by their intrinsic limited energy density [1–3]. Secondary batteries with Li metal as anode show a great advantage in high-energy density due to a remarkably high theoretical capacity (3860mAhg−1) and a remarkably low reduction potential (−3.04V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) of Li metal, making them more competitive than those of commercialized LIBs [4–8]. However, the application of the Li metal anode is hindered by serious safety concerns caused by the uneven deposition of Li and the growth of Li dendrites, large volume change, and a low Coulombic efficiency due to the continuous consumption of electrolyte from an unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer [9–11].

To address the above problems concerning the Li anodes, various approaches have been employed, including optimizing electrolyte constituents [5,12,13], applying 3D current collector [10,14,15], plating an artificial SEI [11,16–19], building a robust host [18,20], and utilizing advanced separators [21]. Electrolyte additives, such as polysulfides, LiNO3, H2O, vinylene carbonate, and fluoroethylene carbonate have been proven to be a straightforward and efficacious strategy to suppress the growth of dendritic Li, or to form a stable and uniform SEI layer on the Li surface [22–25]. In particular, some selected alkaline cations with a reduction potential below that of Li+, have exhibited impressive capability for dendrite suppression of Li anode since their discovery by Zhang and co-workers in 2013 [26]. A compelling dendrite-free morphology was achieved using Cs+ cations as an additive through the self-healing electrostatic shield mechanism. However, a relatively low Coulombic efficiency of 76.6% indicates that the unavoidable Li reaction with electrolyte and the unstable SEI layer generated on the Li surface. The nanoscale Al2O3 layer on bulk Li metal electrode has stimulated research interest due to its high mechanical strength and good ionic conductivity. As pointed out by the researchers, the nanoscale Al2O3 layer can effectively stabilize the Li/electrolyte interface and protect the Li metal against the corrosion in electrolytes [27,28]. Unfortunately, the high instability of Li towards the air and the high complexity of the atomic layer deposition technique have limited its further practical applications. Therefore, exploring one facile and effective strategy not only to regulate the Li plating/stripping behavior but also to form a stable SEI layer with highly ionical conductivity at nanoscale on the Li surface is highly desirable.

Herein, we propose a controllable AlCl3 to be an efficient electrolyte additive for both the dendrite-free Li deposition of Li anode and the stable SEI layer on the surface of Li through a series of reactions between AlCl3 and trace water in carbonate electrolytes during the Li deposition process. The Coulombic efficiency of Li deposition approaches ~99% at 0.5mAcm−2 due to the superior capability of dendrite suppression, and the high mechanical strength and stability of the as-formed SEI film. In addition, rechargeable metal Li batteries (e.g., Li|Se and Li|Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) batteries) have been successfully constructed to demonstrate their practicality in those metallic batteries in electrolyte containing AlCl3; these batteries can deliver a remarkably stable life cycle (more than 500 cycles) compared with their control counterparts.

Fig. 1 illustrates the Li plating process in the electrolyte with AlCl3 additive. As a certain amount of AlCl3 is added into a carbonate electrolyte, residual H2O in the electrolyte preferentially reacts with Al3+, which is a hydrolysis reaction, to generate Al(OH)3 nanosize particles. The as-obtained Al(OH)3 nanosize colloidal particles in the electrolyte will absorb the excess Al3+ that does not participate in the hydrolysis reaction to form the positively charged colloidal particles (PCCPs) (Fig. 1a). Subsequently, the as-generated Al2O3 particles will precipitate on the surface of the Li anode, and form a thin and dense Al-containing SEI layer (Fig. 1b). The Li will be deposited to the adjacent regions of the protruding Li due to the charge repelling and steric hindrance effect of the PCCPs (Fig. 1c), which also enables a uniform and dendrite-free Li morphology during the deposition process (Fig. 1d). Consequently, PCCPs will settle on these Li tips that have appeared, thereby forming a thin and dense Al-containing SEI layer on the surface under an applied voltage, which is similar with the “self-healing” process of the SEI layer (Fig. 1d).

The electrolyte consisted of 1M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)/dimethyl carbonate (DMC)/diethyl carbonate(DEC) (1:1:1 in wt%) purchased from Zhangjiagang Guotai Huarong New Chemical Materials Co., Ltd. and used without further purification. Aluminum chloride (AlCl3) anhydrous powder with a purity of >99.999% was obtained from sigma-Aldrich. Electrolytes containing AlCl3 additive were prepared by dissolving stoichiometric amounts of AlCl3 into the LiPF6 (EC/DMC/DEC) solution inside a glovebox. LTO and Se/MPC were prepared as reported in our previous works. All the Se/MPC composite contains 55wt% Se. Specific capacity is calculated based on the mass of Se.

Li metal was deposited on Cu foil substrates (with a diameter of 10mm) in 1.0M LiPF6 (EC/DMC/DEC) electrolyte solution without or with AlCl3 as an additive at 0.5mAcm−2 for 2mAhcm−2. Li|Li symmetric cells were assembled with Li metal used as the working and counter electrodes to evaluate the cycling stability and cycle life of the Li anodes in 1.0M LiPF6 (EC/DMC/DEC) electrolyte without or with AlCl3 as an additive. After deposition, cycled coin cells were dissembled in a glovebox to obtain Li anode. Before testing, the disassembled electrodes were rinsed with DMC solvent to remove residual electrolytes and Li salts and then dried in the glove box prior to characterizations. Ex situ SEM (6701F, operating at 10kV) was performed to characterize the surface and cross-sections of the deposited Li electrodes. EDX elemental analysis (Tecnai83 F20) was employed to detect the elemental compositions of the Li anode. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement of the compositions and elemental valence of the SEI layer was conducted by ESCALab220i-XL electron spectrometer (VG Scientific) with 300W Al Kα radiation. AFM was conducted on a commercial AFM (Bruker Multimode 8 with a Nanoscope V controller) in an Ar-filled glove box to detect the morphology and the Young's modulus of the Li anode.

To prepare the working electrodes, we mixed the active materials LTO and Se/MPC with a super-P acetylene black and binder (polyvinylidene fluoride) and an aqueous-based binder (carboxymethyl cellulose; CMC) combined with emulsified styrene butadiene (SBR; (CMC/SBR)), respectively, at a weight ratio of 80:10:10. Slurry was formed and then pasted on an aluminum foil and dried. The cells were assembled with Se/MPC and LTO cathode, a Celgard separator, a Li foil and 30μL of electrolyte. Then the GDC cycling of the assembled cells was performed using an Arbin BT2000 system at a voltage range of 1.0V to 2.5V and 1.0V to 2.8V (vs. Li+/Li) for LTO and Se/MPC, respectively. After 500 cycles, Li anodes were taken out of the cells and washed with DMC for SEM observations and EDX analysis. Electrochemical impedance spectra measurement was conducted on the Autolab with frequency range from 100kHz to 0.1Hz. The ionic conductivity of electrolytes was measured using conductivity meter (DDS-307A).

Among the screened liquid electrolytes, ether-based electrolytes have attracted promising attention due to their high compatibility with Li metal anodes [5,29]. However, the poor stability of ether-based electrolytes against oxidation higher than ≈4.0V impedes their application [30]. In comparison with ether-based electrolytes, carbonate electrolytes have been extensively used in current LIBs for their wide electrochemical stability window of more than 4.0V [29,31]. However, Li metal in carbonate-based electrolytes generally exhibits remarkably more conspicuous dendritic Li morphology and significantly lower Coulombic efficiency (e.g., 85%) due to the high reactivity of carbonate electrolytes with Li metal [26,32,33]. In this study, the carbonate electrolytes with different amounts of AlCl3 additives ranging from 0wt% to 10wt% were investigated through deposition tests. Li deposition was conducted on the Cu substrates under a current density of 0.5mAcm−2 for 2mAhcm−2. The Li deposited in the electrolyte without AlCl3 additive exhibits amounts of random growth of protuberant Li ( Fig. 2a). These dendrites with a protruding structure not only contribute to high surface, as well as a possibility of dead Li upon cycling, but also threatens the safety of batteries by piercing the separator upon further cycles. As shown in Fig. S1, a distinct plating Li morphology is observed even when only 1wt% AlCl3 is introduced into the electrolyte, whereas the addition of 8wt% AlCl3 results in a smoother and more uniform Li deposition morphology without Li protrusion (Fig. 2b and S2). However, a higher concentration of added AlCl3 (10wt%) leads to the significant decrease of the ionic conductivity of liquid electrolyte because of the coordination of Al species with the liquid electrolyte constituents, which is detrimental for practical applications (Fig. S3) [34,35]. The results demonstrate that the best Li deposition behavior can be achieved by adding 8wt% of AlCl3. Therefore, the detailed Li plating processes in 1.0M LiPF6 (EC/DMC/DEC) electrolyte containing 0wt% (control) and 8wt% AlCl3 additives are discussed.

Fig. S4 displays the optical images of the metallic Li deposited on the Cu foils without and with 8wt% AlCl3 additive. The Li deposited in the control electrolyte shows a typical dendrite behavior with sporadically protuberant morphology (Fig. S4a). On the contrary, the Li deposited in the AlCl3 electrolyte presents a remarkably even and compact Li surface with inconspicuous dendrite (Fig. S4b). The morphology and the Young’s modulus of the Li anode in the AlCl3 electrolyte were further characterized utilizing the peak force tapping (PFT) mode of the atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Figs. 2c–d). The Li anode with AlCl3 additive exhibits a smooth surface composed of abundant nanoparticles, and a Young’s modulus of ≈2GPa, demonstrating the form of some complex film on the Li surface, which is different from the self-generated SEI films in the commonly used carbonate electrolyte. Usually, the as-generated SEI films are porous and fragile with a lower shear modulus of <1GPa [36]. The SEI layer with a smooth surface and a strong mechanical strength is expected to improve the interfacial stability and dendrite suppression significantly.

Ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carefully conducted to characterize the composition of the SEI film, further exploring the mechanism related to the smooth Li deposition in the electrolyte with AlCl3 additive. The SEI layer is mainly composed of Li, C, O, F, and Al. In the C1s spectra in Fig. 3a, the peaks at ≈286.5, 288.5, 289.7, and 290eV are assigned to C–C–O, C–O–CO2Li, Li2 CO3, and ROCO2Li, respectively, which originate from the decomposition of the solvents [17,37]. The O1s spectra can be fitted into three peaks at 529.8, 531.2 and 532.7eV, which are attributed to LiOH (ROLi), Li2CO3 (Al2O3) and C–O–CO2Li, respectively (Fig. 3b) [37,38]. In the O1s spectrum, the characteristic peak of Al2O3 overlaps with that of Li2CO3 due to their slightly close binding energy. In the case of the F1s spectrum of the SEI film, the peak located at 684eV corresponds to LiF, whereas the peak at 686eV ascribes to the AlF3 and LiPF6 absorbed on Li metal surface (Fig. 3c) [17,39]. The Al 2p spectra collected in Fig. 3d show a binding energy of 74.5eV for the SEI layer in the AlCl3-added electrolyte. Giving the O1s peak (531.2eV), the peak located at 74.5eV is assigned to the formed Al–O bond derived from the Al2O3, which is caused by the reaction of trace H2O and Al3+ [40,41]. An extra peak centred at 76.5eV can be assigned to AlF3, which may be as a consequence of the further reaction of HF and Al2O3 [42]. Based on the XPS results, the surface composition of the SEI layer in the AlCl3-added electrolyte contains the common lithium alkyl carbonate, inorganic crystalline components such as Li2CO3, LiOH and LiF; moreover, it contains an abundance of high mechanical strength and highly ionically-conductive Al2O3 and AlF3, which is beneficial to rapid Li+ diffusion and well dendrite suppression, thereby enabling superior rate capability and long lifespan for a practical Li battery [43].

Based on the above results, a possible evolution process of Al-containing SEI layer can be ascribed follows. When Li foils are immersed into the electrolytes with AlCl3 additives for 20h, Al3+ can spontaneously react with H2O to produce Al(OH)3 nanoparticles and precipitate on the surface of Li foil, thereby serving as an SEI film (Fig. S5 and S6). The deposited SEI layer becomes dense and smooth as the concentration of AlCl3 is increased. At the initial plating stage, H2O can be electrochemically reduced at the anode to generate H2 and OH– [9,44,45].

Li|Cu cells were assembled to examine the Li stripping/plating efficiency and stability in various electrolytes. The initial Coulombic efficiency reaches 75% in the electrolyte with AlCl3 and stabilizes at 99% after several cycles, which is considerably higher than those in the control electrolytes ( Fig. 4a). The Coulombic efficiency remains stable for over 150 cycles. The improvement in Coulombic efficiency demonstrates the effective mitigation of Li reacting with the electrolyte, and the formation of a stable SEI layer on the surface of the Li anode. The results are also supported by the comparison of the voltage hysteresis of the Li anode in the two electrolytes. The Li anode with AlCl3 reveals a lower and more stable voltage hysteresis (less than 30mV even over 150 cycles), whereas the control Li anode shows a constant increase in voltage hysteresis that peaks at above 300mV in less than 70 cycles (Fig. 4b).

Symmetrical Li|Li coin cells were assembled to evaluate the long-term cycling stability of the Li anode in the two electrolytes. The symmetrical cell in the control electrolyte exhibits significant overpotential tips and bumps at the beginning and at the end of each plating and stripping cycle (Fig. 4c). This phenomenon can be explained by the high specific kinetic hindrance for non-uniform Li deposition and dissolution originating from the variation of electrode surface and morphology upon cycling [46–48]. After cycling for 70h, a prompt increase in hysteresis appears, resulting in cell failure. This phenomenon can be ascribed to drying of the electrolyte, and/or decomposition caused by the constant reaction of the Li dendrites with electrolyte and the progressive formation of “dead Li”. By contrast, the cell in the electrolyte with AlCl3 displays a relatively flat voltage platform with a negligible voltage fluctuation, indicating that Li plating/stripping in this system is more easily initiated and maintained [49]. This phenomenon can be ascribed to a reduction in the activation energy barrier, which is due to a stable and thin SEI layer generated on the electrode surface and an even Li growth [46]. The voltage platform maintains throughout the entire cycle without any significant increment. Short circuit is not observed at even cycling for approximately 940h (~235 cycles), which indicates an effective suppression of dendrite growth.

Li|selenium/microporous carbon (Se/MPC) and Li|LTO full cells were tested in the two electrolytes to explore the feasibility of AlCl3 in practical batteries. After the initial three cycles, the Li anode in the control electrolyte exhibits numerous mossy and filament-like Li dendrite morphologies ( Fig. 5a and S7a); however, dendritic Li and a relatively smooth surface is not observed for the anode in the electrolyte with AlCl3 (Fig. 5b and S7b). The Se/MPC battery with AlCl3 electrolyte exhibits lower polarization, higher capacity retention, more stable cycling performance, and higher Coulombic efficiency than the control battery (Figs. 5c and d). For the control battery, significant capacity decay is observed, which may be ascribed to ceaseless consumption of electrolyte caused by the growth of protruding Li. Ex situ SEM was conducted to visualize the morphological characteristics of the cycled Li anodes. After 500 cycles, the control Li anode exhibits a loose and porous structure with a thickness of 400–500µm (Fig. S8a and S8c). The protected Li anode still exhibits a smooth and impact structure composed of C, O, F, Al, P, and Cl without obvious protruding dendrites (Fig. S8b, S8d, and S8f). Apart from the favorable long-term cycling performance, the Se/MPC cathodes in the AlCl3 electrolytes show superior rate capability (Fig. 5e and S9). At a rate of 0.5C, the Se/MPC cathode with AlCl3 electrolytes can deliver approximately the theoretical capacity of selenium (675mAhg−1). Even at a high rate of 5C, the Se/MPC cathode can exhibit a high capacity of 560mAhg−1, which is significantly higher than that of the control Se/MPC cathode of at 440mAhg−1 (Fig. 5e). Likewise, the assembled Li|LTO cells in the AlCl3 electrolyte demonstrate smaller polarization, higher electrochemical stability, better capacity retention, and dendrite suppression (Fig. S10 and S11). The superior electrochemical performance of a practical Li battery can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the robust structure of the formed SEI layer and PCCPs, which can effectively suppress the growth of Li dendrite and afford to highly stabilize the Li/electrolyte interface, as well as initiate Li+ transfer kinetics. Electrochemical Impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was further performed to investigate the SEI/electrode interfacial stability during cycling process. Before cycling, the assembled cell without additive exhibits relative lower initial RSEI than that of the cell with AlCl3 electrolyte (Fig. S12a). Once a SEI layer is formed, a stable SEI/electrode interface appears corresponding to low impedances at high frequency (Fig. S12b). However, the RSEI for the control electrode increases upon cycling, which can be originated from the highly resistive SEI layer and the repeated reductive decomposition of electrolyte owning to Li reacting with the organic electrolyte. Comparing with the control electrode, after 500 cycles at 1C, the electrode cycled in the AlCl3 electrolyte shows smaller SEI/electrode impedance while displays nearly identical charge transfer and ion diffusion impedance (Fig. S12c), indicating that the in situ formed SEI layer containing abundant Al2O3 and AlF3 could remarkably improve the interfacial stability between the SEI and electrode, ensuring long lifespan.

In summary, we successfully realize a dendrite-free Li deposition through the synergism of robust SEI layer and the induction of charged colloidal particles. The key-enabling technique is the use of AlCl3 additive that reacts with trace H2O in the electrolyte to produce a stable Al2O3-rich SEI layer on the surface of the substrate and PCCPs. As a result, a uniform distribution of the ionic flux is realized and the undesirable dendrite growth is prevented, enabling a high Li stripping/plating efficiency approaching to ~99% at 0.5mAcm−2 in carbonate electrolyte. Furthermore, Li-metal secondary batteries with AlCl3 additive demonstrate superior cycling performance, rate capability, and well suppressed Li dendrites. This approach exhibits a new and cost-effective strategy in addressing dendritic formation and improving the stability of Li/electrolyte interface, which can provide a new vision for the research of other rechargeable metal batteries (such as Na and Zn).

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This work was supported by the National Key R&D Program of China (Grant No. 2016YFA0202500), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 51225204, U1301244, and 21127901), the “Strategic Priority Research Program” of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (Grant No. XDA09010300), and the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.nanoen.2017.04.056.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Huan Ye is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Prof. Yu-Guo Guo at Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (ICCAS). Her research focuses on advanced nanocomposite cathode materials and lithium metal anode for rechargeable lithium batteries.

Ya-Xia Yin is an associate Professor at ICCAS. She received her Ph.D. in Beijing University of Chemical Technology. Her research focuses on nanostructured electrode materials for advanced Li-ion and Li-S batteries.

Shuai-Feng Zhang is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Prof. Yu-Guo Guo at ICCAS. He received his B.S. at Zhengzhou University and M.S. at ICCAS. His research focuses on the development of cathode materials and electrolytes for Li-S and Li-Se batteries.

Yang Shi obtained his B.S. at University of Science and Technology of China in 2014. He is currently a Ph.D. student at ICCAS. His research interests focus on visualization of evolution of anode electrode interface using in situ EC-AFM.

Lin Liu is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Prof. Li-Jun Wan and Prof. Yu-Guo Guo at ICCAS. She received her B.S. in Materials Chemistry from Zhengzhou University in 2013. Her research focuses on the design and synthesis of electrode materials and their application in lithium metal batteries.

Xian-Xiang Zeng is currently a Ph.D. student under the supervision of Professor Yu-Guo Guo at ICCAS. His research interests are the design and fabrication of solid electrolytes, and its application in solid lithium batteries and flexible devices with ink-jetting printing.

Rui Wen received her Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from ICCAS in 2008. She worked at the WPI-Advanced Institute for Materials Research (WPI-AIMR), Tohoku University in Japan as a Research Assistant from 2008 to 2011. Then she moved to Institute of Physical and Chemical Research (RIKEN) in Japan as a postdoctoral fellow. In 2013 she received Humboldt postdoctoral research foundation for working at Kiel University in Germany from 2013 to 2015. In 2015 she joined ICCAS as a Professor of Physical Chemistry. Her research interests focus on interfacial electrochemistry, scanning probe microscopy and it's application in energy storage with batteries.

Yu-Guo Guo is a Professor of Chemistry at ICCAS. He received his Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from ICCAS in 2004. He worked at the Max Planck Institute for Solid State Research at Stuttgart (Germany) first as a Guest Scientist and then a Staff Scientist from 2004 to 2007. He joined ICCAS as a full professor in 2007. His research focuses on nanostructured energy materials and electrochemical energy storage devices, such as Li-ion, Li-S and solid lithium batteries.

Li-Jun Wan is a president of University of Science and Technology of China. He received his B.S. and M.S. degrees in Materials Science from Dalian University of Technology in 1982 and 1987, respectively, and Ph.D. in Materials Chemistry from Tohoku University of Japan in 1996. His research focuses on the physical chemistry of single molecules and molecular assemblies, nanomaterials for applications in energy and environmental science, and scanning probe microscopy.
